text: I would start with <https://julia.quantecon.org/index_toc.html|quantecon> if you haven't already, then once you have a basic overview of how things interact, <https://sciml.ai/|sciml> would be the second step.

attachments.title: Table of Contents
attachments.text: This website presents a set of lectures on quantitative economic modeling, designed and written by Jesse Perla, Thomas J. Sargent and John Stachurski.
attachments.fallback: Quantitative Economics with Julia: Table of Contents

text:
Yes, it is awesome, too. But, again, I went through it. Differential Equations part was nice though. But, I was seeking something which is based on economics.

I think, I should work on econ-ML stuff from python/R and start from there. Difficult to find something in Julia, haha, not many folks started preferring to performance.
